With the news that national percentages for medical school
acceptances have gone down in recent years, pre-meds here
have reacted with alarm and dismay to what they consider to
be their diminishing chances, giving rise to rumors that the
acceptance rate at Hopkins has plummeted to 30 per cent or
some such catastrophic figure.
In reality, the chances for a Hopkins pre-med getting into
medical school are pretty much what they have been for the
last five or six years, though recent figures do reflect a slight
decline. The villain here is neither the Recommendations
Committee, nor the quality of the institution, but rather the
enormous increase in aspiring physicians.
Though the Dean's office is in part to blame for witholding
what data it does have on pre-med acceptance in the past few
years, it was the pre-meds themselves who gave in to some
untold paranoia and began circulating horror stories. In truth,
as Dr. Martin Larrabee has pointed out, an abstract
acceptance figure should be of genuine concern to a pre-med
only if it is zero of 100 per cent. For there is not that much
an institution can do to jeopardize or improve a med school
applicant's prospects. The acceptance percentage reflects the
results of all applications, regardless of the academic record
of the individual. As always, the chances depend on the
individual.
Though an open meeting to discuss the figures is in the
offing, prospective medical school applicants would do well
to avoid such a needless source of anxiety, concentrate on
the efficacy of their own individual chances, and be wary of
statistical bogeymen which obfuscate, rather than clarify, the
issue at hand.

Dr. Joseph Sampson's remarks about the undergraduate
instructional programs in his department indicate clearly
where the problems lie in the teaching of the Mathematics
Department—communication. There is certainly no lack of
willingness on the part of Sampson or his department to
correct any deficiencies in undergraduate teaching. In fact,
the measures already taken by the Math Department
demonstrate that there is a willingness on the part of the
Department. The problem, it seems, is that the Department
does not fully comprehend what the problems are.
Sampson reasons that because no undergraduates have
come to hime with complaints, students must be relatively
satisfied with the teaching in the Department. And yet,
undergraduate dissatisfaction is registered, in the Student
Council's Academic Reports. Moreover, it is fairly evident
that the fundamental problems in the instructional programs
stem from the mechanics of the courses, but more
significantly, from the very orientation of the Department.
The Math Department does not seem to realize, according to
the Academic Reports at least, that the majority of students
in the introductory courses arc interested in math only in so
far as it applies to other disciplines.
If the Math Department is intent on improving its teaching
programs, it would do well to heed the recommendations
made by the Student Council which have been echoed
numerous times before by students and faculty alike. Either
the Math Department should make introductory required
courses more applicable to the studies of undergraduates, or
these courses should be taught in the Math Sciences
Department, a department set up for the study of applied
mathematics.
The Math Department suffers from a condition similar to
that of many students enrolled in the Department's intro
courses. In both cases, it's not that there is a lack of
willingness to learn, but that there is a difference in
orientation that must be broached before communication
and learning can occur.

pre-med
With the news that national percentages for medical school
acceptances have gone down in recent years, pre-meds here
have reacted with alarm and dismay to what they consider to
be their diminishing chances, giving rise to rumors that the
acceptance rate at Hopkins has plummeted to 30 per cent or
some such catastrophic figure.
In reality, the chances for a Hopkins pre-med getting into
medical school are pretty much what they have been for the
last five or six years, though recent figures do reflect a slight
decline. The villain here is neither the Recommendations
Committee, nor the quality of the institution, but rather the
enormous increase in aspiring physicians.
Though the Dean's office is in part to blame for witholding
what data it does have on pre-med acceptance in the past few
years, it was the pre-meds themselves who gave in to some
untold paranoia and began circulating horror stories. In truth,
as Dr. Martin Larrabee has pointed out, an abstract
acceptance figure should be of genuine concern to a pre-med
only if it is zero of 100 per cent. For there is not that much
an institution can do to jeopardize or improve a med school
applicant's prospects. The acceptance percentage reflects the
results of all applications, regardless of the academic record
of the individual. As always, the chances depend on the
individual.
Though an open meeting to discuss the figures is in the
offing, prospective medical school applicants would do well
to avoid such a needless source of anxiety, concentrate on
the efficacy of their own individual chances, and be wary of
statistical bogeymen which obfuscate, rather than clarify, the
issue at hand.

Dr. Joseph Sampson's remarks about the undergraduate
instructional programs in his department indicate clearly
where the problems lie in the teaching of the Mathematics
Department—communication. There is certainly no lack of
willingness on the part of Sampson or his department to
correct any deficiencies in undergraduate teaching. In fact,
the measures already taken by the Math Department
demonstrate that there is a willingness on the part of the
Department. The problem, it seems, is that the Department
does not fully comprehend what the problems are.
Sampson reasons that because no undergraduates have
come to hime with complaints, students must be relatively
satisfied with the teaching in the Department. And yet,
undergraduate dissatisfaction is registered, in the Student
Council's Academic Reports. Moreover, it is fairly evident
that the fundamental problems in the instructional programs
stem from the mechanics of the courses, but more
significantly, from the very orientation of the Department.
The Math Department does not seem to realize, according to
the Academic Reports at least, that the majority of students
in the introductory courses arc interested in math only in so
far as it applies to other disciplines.
If the Math Department is intent on improving its teaching
programs, it would do well to heed the recommendations
made by the Student Council which have been echoed
numerous times before by students and faculty alike. Either
the Math Department should make introductory required
courses more applicable to the studies of undergraduates, or
these courses should be taught in the Math Sciences
Department, a department set up for the study of applied
mathematics.
The Math Department suffers from a condition similar to
that of many students enrolled in the Department's intro
courses. In both cases, it's not that there is a lack of
willingness to learn, but that there is a difference in
orientation that must be broached before communication
and learning can occur.
